abstract.p: In this paper we present the generalized Fourier series solution for the transverse vibration of a beam subjected to a viscous end condition in the form of a torsional damper. The model of the system produces a nonself-adjoint eigenvalue-like problem that does not yield orthogonal eigenfunctions; therefore, such functions cannot be used to calculate the coefficients of expansion in the Fourier series. Furthermore, the eigenfunctions and eigenvalues are complex valued. Nevertheless, the eigenfunctions can be utilized if the space of the operator is extended and a suitable inner product is defined. The methodology presented in the paper utilizes Hilbert space methods and is applicable in general to other problems of this type. As an adjunct to the theoretical discussion, the results from numerical simulations are presented.

sec.title: 1. Introduction
sec.p: This paper presents an investigation of the problem of a transverse vibration of a clamped beam subjected to a torsional damper at the boundary. This type of problem arises in situations where viscous dampers are used to control the displacement of structures. The vibration of discrete spring-viscous damping structures attached to a beam was considered in Bergman and Nicholson (1985) and Sciulli (1997) as the vibration of so-called ‘combined dynamical systems’. In the first reference the authors used the separation of variables and the Green function method to determine the vibration response assuming homogeneous boundary conditions. Discrete damped oscillators were located arbitrarily along the span of the beam, but not at the boundary. Similarly, in the second reference the author considered the same systems using the transfer function synthesis method for obtaining the vibration response. These references, however, do not consider dampers at the boundary. Unfortunately, such boundary conditions drastically change the mathematical nature of the problem. As a result, the nonself-adjointness arises, which makes the methods utilized in these references inadequate for the problem discussed here. The reason for this is that dampers at the boundary introduce a spectral parameter into the boundary conditions of the underlying eigenvalue problem, which in turn produces complex eigenvalues and nonorthogonal complex eigenmodes. Consequently, expanding the response into nonorthogonal eigenmodes becomes problematic since the coefficients of expansion are very difficult to determine. Furthermore, even how to apply the approximate procedures, such as the Galerkin method, is unclear since the Galerkin method presupposes that basis functions satisfy the same boundary conditions. The only available procedure is the Laplace transform together with the Green function method, where Green's function must be expanded into partial fractions. Then, the coefficients of expansion must be obtained with the integration in the complex domain. This, however, is a nontrivial task and to the best of our knowledge it has not been attempted for the problem considered here.

Attempts to treat nonself-adjoint boundary conditions in the engineering literature are sparse perhaps because the vast majority of cases lead to a self-adjoint mathematical description. However, a few references exist, such as Prater and Singh (1991), Hull (1994), Oliveto et al. (1997), Singh et al. (1989), and Gürgöze and Erol (2006), which provide certain insight into the nonself-adjoint nature of longitudinal vibrations of bars and transverse vibrations of beams. Singh et al. (1989) and Hull (1994) treat longitudinal vibrations of a bar. Hull (1994) demonstrates how difficult it is to obtain a series solution even in the simpler case of the wave equation and only for harmonic input forcing. Oliveto et al. (1997) derive appropriate orthogonality conditions through an involved algebraic manipulation, which results in the decoupled system of equations for the case of a simply supported beam with two torsional dampers at the boundaries. Gürgöze and Erol (2006) closely follow Oliveto et al. (1997) and attempt to find an appropriate orthogonality condition for the clamped-damper beam that decouples the system of equations in order to apply the Galerkin method. This, however, is not without problems since the derived orthogonally condition fails to completely decouple the system of equations. This points to how difficult it is to correctly treat nonself-adjoint problems. We emphasize that the nature of nonself-adjointness is embedded in the underlying boundary eigenvalue problem, which contains a spectral parameter in the boundary conditions. The analysis of such boundary value problems (BVPs) and their treatment can be found in Tamarkin (1928) and Orazov and Shkalikov (1976), where the more general form of the eigenvalue problem with a spectral parameter in the boundary conditions was considered. The methodology presented there can be used to calculate the expansion coefficients of Green's function mentioned above.

In this paper we avoid any of the complexities discussed above by simply transferring the equation of motion of the beam into the first-order form. This transfers the underlying BVP to a standard form that does not contain the spectral parameter in the boundary conditions. Consequently, our technique utilizes Hilbert space methods by extending the definition of the linear operator involved to a vector space and defining a suitable inner product. As a result of that we achieve the orthogonality of eigenvectors which enables us to calculate all of the coefficients of the generalized Fourier's series in the standard way. This paper therefore provides a complete series solution to the problem that, to the best of our knowledge, has not been obtained to date.

We organize the presentation as follows. We first state the problem and provide its mathematical description in the form of a partial differential equation. From this equation we derive a BVP and determine eigenfunctions and eigenvalues. These will be complex valued due to nonself-adjointness. We then analyze the differential operator and recast the BVP into a state-space form that does not contain the spectral parameter in the boundary conditions and that yields orthogonal eigenvectors. We then perform the modal analysis together with the Laplace transform and write a response of the system in terms of eigenfunction expansion. Finally, we provide numerical illustrations. The effectiveness of the procedure can be measured with the simplicity of obtaining the orthogonality condition that is needed to calculate all of the coefficients of Fourier series just as is the case for the self-adjoint problems.

sec.title: 2. Problem statement
sec.p:
We begin with the problem statement of the system. Figure 1 depicts a beam clamped at one end and suspended with a torsional damper at the other. The symbols ρ, A0, E, and I represent the mass density of the beam, constant cross-sectional area, the modulus of elasticity, and the moment of inertia, respectively. The coefficient c1 represent a damping coefficient of the damper. Figure 1.
A beam with a torsional damper at the right-hand boundary.

The equation of motion is provided as (1) with its associated boundary (2) and initial conditions (3) where c2=EIρA0 and h=c1EI, assuming c1 is positive. f(x) and g(x) are assumed real square-integrable functions representing initial displacement and velocity of the beam, respectively. p(x,t) is the force per unit mass distributed along the length of the beam, while u(x,t) is a displacement coordinate, which is appropriately labeled in Figure 1. We note that we must have f(0) = 0, f′(0) = 0, and g(0) = 0.

For a nontrivial solution to exist, the determinant of the matrix of this system must be equal to zero. Writing this determinant in terms of β, and recognizing that β≠0 since there is no rigid body mode present in the system, yields (10)

Figure 2 shows that Equation (10) will be satisfied with four roots ±β and ±iβ¯, where the bar over β represents the complex conjugate. In view of our definition for β2, the roots ±β will lead to λ and ±iβ¯ will lead to λ¯. Therefore, we can select only one solution from each pair as relevant and discard the other. These two solutions used in Equation (8) provide an appropriate vector basis for spanning the Hilbert space. The other two lead to another possible vector basis.

Furthermore, Figure 2 suggests an additional pair of roots on the diagonal ζ passing through the left upper and bottom right quadrant of the complex plane. Since this pair appears to be on ζ we attempt a substitution β=q−iq (or β=−q+iq) in Equation (10). It can be clearly seen that there exist only two solutions ±q satisfying Equation (11) and therefore only one possible pair β=q−iq and β=−q+iq on diagonal ζ. Either of these two roots leads to a real eigenvalue λ=−2q2c, which again indicates that only one β can be used for computing the corresponding eigenfunction. Figure 3.

sec.title: 4. Adjoint operator and Fourier's expansion
sec.p: As we pointed out in the previous section, the BVP is not self-adjoint and a direct approach to solving our problem by using eigenfunctions is not possible since they are not orthogonal. Therefore, we proceed further with more general methods developed in the theory of Hilbert spaces. We first recast our equation of motion into a state-space representation of the first-order form by defining a state and excitation vector: (14) and a matrix differential operator (15)
With these definitions our equation of motion attains the first-order form (16) with initial (17) and boundary conditions (18)

Comparing this BVP to the one in Equation (5), we see that the eigenvalue is not contained in the boundary conditions. The problem is still not self-adjoint, but it will now be possible to obtain the orthogonality condition that decouples the state-space representation (16).

Comparing the integral on the left-hand side of Equation (22) with the integral on the right-hand side, we see that in order for the equation to hold, it must be that g¯1(x)=v¯″2(x) and g¯2(x)=−c2v¯″2(x). We obtain the boundary conditions for the adjoint problem by setting the surface term to zero: (24)

Substituting the boundary conditions from Equation (20) into Equation (24) and identically equating to zero the terms multiplying u1(L), u2(0), u′1(0), and u′1(L), we obtain the boundary conditions for the adjoint eigenvalue problem. The adjoint eigenvalue problem then becomes (25) where μ is the eigenvalue of operator T*. We see immediately that T∗=TT, implying T≠T∗, and demonstrating further that T is a nonself-adjoint operator. This confirms the nonself-adjointness of the BVP, Equation (5).

We thus obtain a relation (26) that is satisfied when u is any element of D and v is any element of D*, where D and D* represent the set of eigenvectors satisfying associated boundary conditions for each operator T and T*, respectively. (26)

We now proceed with obtaining the required orthogonality condition. If we substitute Equations (20) and (25) into Equation (26) and use the definition of inner product, we obtain (27) which implies that either λ=μ¯ or < v(x), u(x)> = 0. Therefore, an eigenvector of T corresponding to the eigenvalue λ is orthogonal to every eigenvector of T* for which μ≠λ¯.

So far, we have obtained an orthogonality condition that relates λ with μ through eigenfunctions, but we still do not know how the set of all λs and μs are related. To determine that, we proceed as follows. We first state a result that can be proved, that is, either there exists for any vector f(x), a vector v(x) in the domain of T* such that (T∗−λ¯I)v(x)=f(x), or there exists a nontrivial solution to (T∗−λ¯I)v(x)=0 and therefore an eigenvector of T* corresponding to value λ¯.I is the 2 × 2 identity matrix. Based on the result just stated, we shall show that each eigenvalue λ of operator T is also an eigenvalue of T*.
Suppose that u(x) is an eigenvector of T corresponding to the eigenvalue λ, then (T−λI)u(x)=0. Let v(x) be any vector in D*, then in view of Equation (26) and the inner product (28)

This implies that u(x) is orthogonal to every vector of the form (T∗−λ¯I)v(x). If (T∗−λ¯I)v(x) represented every vector f(x) we would have a contradiction, since <u(x),f(x)>=0 for every f(x) would imply that u(x)= 0. Therefore, the other alternative of the result we mentioned must hold, that there exists an eigenvector of T* corresponding to λ¯. This means that for every λ of operator T there is λ¯, which is an eigenvalue of T*. Now, since vector u¯(x) is in the domain of T, equation Tu¯(x)=λ¯u¯(x) implies that λ¯ is also an eigenvalue of T. Consequently, λ=λ¯¯ is also an eigenvalue of T*. Thus, we have just shown that the set of λs of operator T is the same as the set of μs of operator T*.

To determine eigenvectors of T we revert to the BVP specified in Equation (5). The eigenvalues of that problem are the same as eigenvalues of the problem specified in Equation (20). We see now that for λ = 0 the BVP in Equation (20) has only a trivial solution, which cannot be an eigenvector. This is a mathematical explanation of the corresponding nonexistent rigid body mode in the system. Vectors un and vn represent infinite orthonormal bases in X, which can be used to expand any two-component vector F into a series: (32) where (33)

Furthermore, they are the projections onto the basis un and, since the projections are never greater than the original, no piece of the Fourier series can be greater than F. In the limit as n→±∞ the series on the left-hand side of Equation (32) reconstructs F, demonstrating the completeness of the basis.

sec.title: 6. Numerical results
sec.p: How well do the eigenvectors approximate any function on [0, L]? Unfortunately, we do not have a closed form solution to compare our series expansion for any time t in the future. However, it is sufficient to examine the expansion at t = 0 and compare it to initial conditions f(x) and g(x), since these are the only exact solutions available. To this end we choose f(x) = 0.01 x2 and g(x) = 0 for simplicity.
Using the response Equation (50), the displacement error for the beam at time t = 0 is given as (51)

The approximation error from Equation (51) is shown in Figure 5 for different values of parameter k. Figure 5.
Error from Equation (51) for different values of k with c = 1.5, L = 1.8, and h = 0.1.
We see from Figure 5 that the error rapidly reduces as the number of terms in the series is increased. The error is within 10−7 for k = 20.

Table 1 provides the first 20 eigenvalues with the positive imaginary part for different values of parameter h with c = 1.5 and L = 1.8. We provide this table for verification purposes, since it is not straightforward to obtain the eigenvalues by solving Equation (10). The equation is transcendental with infinitely many solutions close to each other and with a bad initial guess a numerical procedure such as Newton–Raphson can easily miss many.

Table 1 shows that only the real part of the second eigenvalue decreases as h increases, rendering the conclusion about the effect of damping affecting the beam more difficult. This eigenvalue should be the dominant pole in the transient-response behavior, since this pole is the nearest to the imaginary axis. Furthermore, the response shown in Figure 6 clearly indicates that the beam loses more energy as h increases which is expected. The graphs a), b) and c) represent the response of the system for f(x) = 0.01 x2, g(x) = 0.03 x, p(x, t) = 0 and h = 0.1, h = 0.3 and h = 0.5 respectively. They confirm that with the increasing value of parameter h the displacement of the beam vanishes more quickly. Figure 6.

sec.title: 7. Conclusions
sec.p: In this paper we studied the dynamics of the transverse vibrations of a beam subjected to a torsional damper at the boundary. The system is not self-adjoint, which prevents one from readily obtaining the orthogonality condition needed for decoupling of the system. Nevertheless, it was possible to deploy Fourier's method and to derive the complete solution of the problem in terms of eigenfunction expansion. The Fourier coefficients were calculated by extending the space of the operator and recasting the underlying eigenvalue problem into the first-order form.

Transverse vibration of a clamped beam with a discrete torsional damper attached at the other end represents only one possibility to obtain nonself-adjointness in the system. Attaching dampers at the boundary to any other continuous structure, such as bars and plates, would introduce a similar situation. To our knowledge such investigations have not been carried out in the engineering literature and only some attempts to obtain approximate solutions, in the case of the beam, have been recently made. However, the methodology described in this paper should in general be applicable with a similar treatment in the case of plates and bars. The case of longitudinal vibrations of a bar with viscous boundaries (to appear) as well as the case of transversal vibrations of a clamped beam with a sheering damper at the boundary have already been analyzed (Jovanovic, 2011).

sec.title: A.2 Formula for Equations (47) and (49)
sec.p: We now want to show that the restriction u′1,r(L) in Equation (A.5) can be relaxed to u′1,r(ξ). Once again, we proceed with the generalized Fourier series by expanding δ(x−ξ) as follows: (A.6)
In view of u2,r(x)=u″1,r(x)λr from Equation (20) and v1,r(x) = u1,r(x), we now write the first component of Equation (A.6) as (A.7)

Equation (A.7) is not a usual series since we are expanding a vector containing Dirac's delta function, which is not a function in the ordinary sense. The series does not converge to zero in the classical sense, but oscillates faster and faster as more terms are added. The series is in fact a distribution and therefore it converges distributionally or ‘weakly’ (Kanwal, 2004). Nevertheless, the series can be used in the ordinary sense for term-by-term integration. We utilize this convergence in this integrated sense and proceed by integrating Equation (A.7) on both sides with respect to ξ to obtain (A.8) where C(x) is a constant of integration combining the constants of integration from both sides of Equation (A.8). To determine it, we set ξ=L in Equation (A.8) and compare this equation to Equation (A.5) after which we conclude that C(x) = 0. Finally, we obtain a generalized summation formula: (A.9) which can be used to simplify the response of the system.

If we continue in the same fashion and integrate Equation (A.9) with respect to ξ we obtain (A.10) where E(x) is a constant of integration combining the constants of integration from both sides of Equation (A.10). This equation must be satisfied for any value of ξ. We can therefore set ξ=0 and recall that u1,r(0) = 0 implying E(x)= 0, which yields the final formula: (A.11)
